results.title: War and peace
results.creator_credit: King Vidor, Dino De Laurentiis, Paramount Pictures and Ponti-De Laurentis
results.brief_description: Based on Leo Tolstoy’s 20th Century masterpiece, it took a decade of preparation and two years of filming to produce this classic version. The personal stories of many characters, love affairs, and philosophies are woven throughout this massive and intricate tapestry of Russia during Napoleon’s invasion at the turn of the 19th Century. With great attention to detail and historical accuracy, this epic becomes an unforgettable document as well as a highly moving drama.

results.title: Malcolm X
results.creator_credit: Spike Lee, Marvin Worth, 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks and Largo Entertainment
results.brief_description: Malcolm X was one of the most controversial American political figures. Based on Alex Haley’s “The Autobiography of Malcolm X”. It is a landmark film in that it has an African-American as the hero of a Hollywood epic. Malcolm X was initially a small-time crim who converted to Islam and became a central figure in the the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s. A passionate and dynamic speaker, his vehement condemnation of race relations fightened and incensed many white Americans. The film faithfully follows Malcolm X’s life: his poor childhood and violent early adulthood, his prison years, his involvement in the Nation of Islam and the Civil Rights Movement, and the lead-up to his assassination. Though a long film of the epic genre, Spike Lee’s direction is colourful and well-paced, and some of the sequences are dazzling, including the pilgrimmage to Mecca. Spike Lee was the first Western filmmaker allowed to film in the Holy City. “Malcolm X” reclaims, with passion and dignity, the life of a controversial but inspiring man. Denzel Washington plays Malcolm X and Angela Bassett plays his wife. Cast alson includes Al Freeman Jr, Albert Hall, Delroy Lindo.

constellations_other.name: MLK/FBI: blackness In America
constellations_other.description: Award-winning documentarian Sam Pollard looks at J. Edgar Hoover and the FBI’s pursuit of Martin Luther King Jr in the lead-up to his assassination during America’s Civil Rights Movement of the sixties.

results.title: Freaks
results.brief_description: This controversial film was banned for over thirty years in some countries, including Australia. Using a group of circus and carnival performers who were all regarded as “freaks of nature” this unsettling film is about a malicious young woman who weds a carnival manager in order to gain his wealth. Her cruel treatment of the various circus performers prompts them to exact a vicious revenge. The final scenes in this movie are possibly some of the most harrowing in horror cinema history.

results.title: Whore
results.creator_credit: Ken Russell, Ronaldo Vasconcellos, Dan Ireland and Trimark Pictures
results.brief_description: Whore tells the story of one night in the life of a prostitute. Liz, (Theresa Russell) is a street wise hooker who has seen it all and done it all. In contrast to “Pretty Woman”, this film does not glamorise prostitution. This is a brash, vulgar depiction of the profession. Although exploitative and titillating in itself, it does raise issues often overlooked in more romantic interpretations, including legalisation, safe sex, drug abuse and the relationship between sex and power.

results.title: The Prince of tides
results.creator_credit: Barbra Streisand, Andrew S Karsch, Longfellow, Barwood Films and Columbia
results.brief_description: New York psychiatrist, Susan Lowenstein (Barbra Streisand) confronts her own private pain when she delves into Tom Wingo’s (Nick Nolte) memories of his family’s past. Together they search for the key that may save Tom’s twin sister who repeatedly attempts suicide. Nick Nolte gives the most heartfelt and powerful performance of his career as a man who, in order to mend his sister’s emotional wounds, must finally come to terms with his own. Based on the best-selling novel by Pat Conroy and nominated for seven Academy Awards, this film is a compelling exploration of love - between men and women, parents and children, and, ultimately, love of oneself.

results.title: Gross misconduct
results.creator_credit: George Miller, David Hannay, Richard Sheffield-MacClure, Underworld Productions, David Hannan Productions and Pro Films
results.brief_description: Justin Thorn (Jimmy Smits) was a popular university professor, envied by his colleagues and desired by his students. Then one young woman’s desire proves to be too great. Jennifer Carter (Naomi Watts) develops an intense infatuation which results in an encounter that gets out of control and ultimately leads to Thorn being charged with her violent rape. Now his career, his family and his freedom are in jeopardy - but was he really the rapist? The plot twists in this explosive and controversial thriller which will mesmerise and haunt you. Co-starring Sarah Chadwick as Thorn’s suffering wife and Brendon Suhr as Carter’s maligned boyfriend.

results.title: The Way we were
results.creator_credit: Sydney Pollack, Ray Stark, Rastar Productions and Columbia
results.brief_description: Barbra Streisand and Robert Redford star in one of Hollywood’s legendary love stories. Redford is the boy who sets out to become the top film writer in Hollywood and Streisand is the outspoken activist. Their love binds them together, but their beliefs put them on a collision course which ultimately tears them apart. Redford is charming as the all-American WASP boy, while Streisands performance as the “blue-stocking” Jewish activist is moving, as she vacillates between fragility and passionate committment to her causes. Although uneven and at times unashamedly sentimental, the film is a classic of its genre. Marvin Hamlisch’s score and the title song earned Oscars for the film.

results.title: Truly madly deeply
results.creator_credit: Anthony Minghella, Robert Cooper and BBC Film Unit
results.brief_description: Acclaimed British actors Juliet Stevenson and Alan Rickman star in this wonderfully moving story of love, loss and letting go. Nina lives in her rat-infested flat where she spends most of her time grieving for her dead lover, Jamie. As if in answer to her dreams, Jamie re-enters her life but Nina discovers that living in the past could mean a life without a future.

results.title: The Public enemy
results.creator_credit: William Wellman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: James Cagney plays Tom Powers, the son of a Chicago policeman, growing up in the city slums where, as a boy, he naturally turns to petty crime as a way of life. As an adult he becomes a successful big-time liquor racketeer. Tom Power has no socially redeemimg traits. He takes pleasure in even the most petty of physical insults, such as grinding half a grapefruit into the startled face of Mae Clark. Cagney’s raw ferocious portrayal of a vicious criminal is masterful and the film is a classic in its genre. Also stars Jean Harlow and Joan Blondell.

results.title: The Lost boys (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Joel Schumacher, Harvey Bernhard and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This popular 1987 film presents an interesting mix of genres: the 1980s teen movie with vampires. Michael and Sam are two brothers who have moved with their mother to Santa Carla, “murder capitol of the world”, unaware of the vampires residing in this fictional Californian Coastal town (the film was shot in Santa Barbara, and includes spectacular footage of the Boardwalk and beach-side amusement park). Michael is charmed by a girl named Star, and immediately falls in with a tough young gang led by David. It’s peer pressure in the extreme as Michael is tricked into drinking blood. He is turned into an unwilling vampire, and Sam looks to a pair of comic book vendors who are well versed in the dealings with vampires, to help save Michael. The insecurities and frustrations of youth are amplified and satirised by this exciting and funny MTV-generation thriller. Cast includes: Jason Patric, Corey Haim, Dianne Wiest, Kiefer Sutherland and Corey Feldman.
